questions.text: A 23-year-old female presents to the clinic with pain, lacrimation, and photophobia in both eyes. The female is a contact lens wearer. A diagnosis of corneal ulceration is made. Which organism is the most common causative organism?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Pseudomonas aeruginosa Common bacteria associated with corneal ulceration include Staphylococci, Pseudomonas, Streptococcus pneumoniae, Enterobacteriaceae, and Neisseria. The most common cause in general is Staphylococcus Most common cause in contact lens wearers is Pseudomonas .

Highyeild:

Pseudomonas is the most common causative organism for corneal ulcers in contact lens wearers. Pseudomonas produces an irregular ulcer with a greenish mucopurulent exudate and diffuse liquefactive necrosis, and semi -opaque (ground glass) surrounding cornea. Such ulcers are usually associated with hypopyon, spread very rapidly, and may even perforate within 48 to 72 hours.

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Streptococcus pneumonia: usually not associated with contact lens users. Option: C. Acanthamoeba: Acanthamoeba keratitis is associated with contaminated saline solutions used for contact lenses. Option: D. Enterobacteriaceae: Usually not associated with contact lens users

questions.text: A 10-year-old male child was brought to OPD for impaired vision and redness in both eyes for 2 weeks. On examination, there were corneal opacities and a salmon patch appearance on the cornea due to deep vascularization of the cornea . The boy had previously been diagnosed with vestibular hearing loss. The parents also complained of having malformed teeth. Which can be the causal organism for the condition?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Treponema Pallidum The condition is syphilitic interstitial keratitis. It presents with corneal opacities, keratic precipitates, and a salmon patch appearance on cornea due to its deep vascularization. It can occur due to congenital syphilis and presents at around 5-15 years age of It may be a part of Hutchinson's triad: interstitial keratitis, H utchinson's teeth. and vestibular deafness.

Highyeild:

Syphilitic (Luetic) Interstitial Keratitis : Syphilitic interstitial keratitis is associated more frequently (90%) with congenital syphilis than with acquired syphilis. The disease is generally bilateral in inherited syphilis and unilateral in acquired syphilis . In congenital syphilis , manifestations develop between 5 and 15 years of age . Pathogenesis It is now generally accepted that the disease is a manifestation of a local antigen-antibody reaction. The inflammation is usually triggered by an injury or an operation on the eye. Clinical features Interstitial keratitis characteristically forms one of the late manifestations of congenital syphilis . Hutchinson's triad, which includes interstitial keratitis, Hutchinson's teeth and vestibular deafness. The clinical features of interstitial keratitis can be divided into three stages : Initial progressive stage, florid rage and stage of regression. Initial progressive stage . The disease begins with oedema of the endothelium and deeper stroma, secondary to anterior uveitis, as evidenced by the presence of keratic precipitates (KPs). There is associated pain, lacrimation, photophobia, blepharospasm, and circumcorneal injection, followed by a diffuse corneal haze giving it a ground-glass appearance. This stage lasts for about 2 weeks. Florid stage . At this stage, the eye remains acutely inflamed. Deep vascularization of the cornea, consisting of a radial bundle of brush-like vessels, develops. Since these vessels are covered by a hazy cornea, they look dull reddish pink, which is called 'Salmon Patch Appearance'. There is often a moderate degree of superficial vascularization. These vessels, arising from the terminal arches of conjunctival vessels, run a short distance over the cornea. This stage lasts for about 2 months. Stage Of Regression . The acute inflammation resolves with the progressive appearance of vascular invasion. Clearing of cornea is slow and begins from the periphery and advances centrally. Resolution of the lesion leaves behind some opacities and ghost vessels. This stage may last for about 1 or 2 years. Interstitial keratitis: Salmon patch appearance Diagnosis The diagnosis is usually evident from the clinical profile. A positive VDRL or Treponema pallidum immobilization test confirms the diagnosis . Treatment Topical treatment for keratitis and systemic treatment for syphilis. Local Treatment includes: Topical corticosteroid drops, e.g., dexamethasone 0.1% drops every 2-3 hours. As the condition is allergic in origin, corneal clearing occurs with steroids if started well in time and a useful vision is obtained. Atropine eye ointment, 1%, 2- 3 times a day. dark goggles to be used for photophobia. Keratoplasty is required in cases where dense corneal opacities are left Systemic treatment includes: Penicillin in high doses should be stained to prevent the development of further syphilitic lesions. However, early treatment of congenital syphilis usually does not prevent the onset of keratitis at a later stage. Systemic steroids may be added in refractory cases of keratitis .

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Neisseria gonorrhoea presents with corneal ulcers. Option: C. mycobacterium tuberculosis presents with interstitial keratitis but is unilateral and involves the lower cornea. Option: D. Herpes zoster virus presents s Herpes zoster ophthalmicus.

questions.text: A soft contact lens user presents to you with pain, watering, photophobia, and a white spot in the center of the cornea. What will the initial management be?

options.label: A
options.text: Start frequent antibiotic eye drops after discontinuing the contact lens

options.label: B
options.text: Pad and bandage the eye for 12-hours

questions.correct_answer: A. Start frequent antibiotic eye drops after discontinuing the contact lens
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Start frequent antibiotic eye drops after discontinuing the contact lens Topical agents include the following: Preservative free artificial tears , used with or without a punctum plug, and soft contact lenses. Small corneal ulcers caused by dry eye syndrome can benefit from such treatment, promoting epithelialization of the ulcer. Cycloplegic agents (e.g., cyclopentolate TID) Immunosuppressive agents (e.g., topical cyclosporine 0.5% in artificial tears) Prophylactic broad-spectrum topical antibiotics (e.g., 0.3% ciprofloxacin q.i.d.) to prevent bacterial superinfection.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: B. Pad and bandage the eye for 12-hours: Pressure bandage should be applied to give some external support. Option: C. Frequent installation of artificial tears: Treatment of dry eye. Option: D. Topical nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs: Used as supportive treatment.

questions.text: A person who has been wearing contact lenses for 1-2 months comes with no irritation in the left eye. Diagnosis: keratitis. Corneal scrapings revealed the presence of Pseudomonas aeruginosa, which was multidrug resistant. How did it attain that level of resistance?

options.label: A
options.text: By transfer of genes from commensal bacteria of eye

options.label: C
options.text: Frequent and prior use of topical antibiotics / steroid preparation

options.label: D
options.text: Ability of pseudomonas to produce biofilm resistant to antibiotics

questions.correct_answer: D. Ability of pseudomonas to produce biofilm resistant to antibiotics
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Ability of pseudomonas to produce biofilm resistant to antibiotics Pseudomonas aeruginosa is one of the six bacterial pathogens, (Enterococcus faecium, Staphylococcus aureus, Klebsiella pneumoniae, Acinetobacter baumannii, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, and Enterobacter spp.) that are commonly associated with antimicrobial resistance , and denoted by their acronym ESKAPE . aeruginosa is also recognized as an important cause of chronic infections due to its ability to form biofilms, where the bacteria are present in aggregates encased in a self-produced extracellular matrix and are difficult or impossible to eradicate with antibiotic treatment.

Highyeild:

Causative organisms of Bacterial keratitis Purulent keratitis is nearly always exogenous due to pyogenic bacteria such as Pseudomonas, Staphylococcus aureus and S. albus, Pneumococcus,Neisseria gonorrhoeae, Escherichia coli, et , which invade the cornea from without. It has been noted that the only organisms known to be able to invade normal corneal epithelium are N. gonorrhoeae and Corynebacterium diphtheriae ; but most other bacteria (e.g., pneumococci) are capable of producing ulceration when the epithelium is damaged . Organisms such as Staphylococcus may initially lead to superficial erosions, which coalesce to form frank ulcers. Mode and source of infection: The principal mode of entry of organisms is through the corneal epithelium as a result of a break in the surface, diminished resistance of the epithelium, necrosis, or desquamation . Although minute abrasions of the cornea are probably an everyday occurrence, highly virulent, pathogenic organisms are not usually present in the conjunctival sac, and if they are, the tear film and the resistance of the normal tissues are sufficient to deal with them. However, there are certain specific predisposing factors that increase the risk of developing corneal ulceration. These are the introduction of organisms during trauma, prolonged use of topical steroids, dry eyes, entropion with trichiasis, lagophthalmos due to neuroparalysis (facial nerve), wearing of contact lenses, bullous keratopathy, and poor local hygiene .

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A . By transfer of genes from commensal bacteria of the eye: aeruginosa is recognized as an important cause of chronic infections due to its ability to form biofilms, where the bacteria are present in aggregates encased in a self-produced extracellular matrix and are difficult or impossible to eradicate with antibiotic treatment. Option: B . Improper contact lens hygiene: this is an important risk factor for acquiring Pseudomonas not the reason for its antimicrobial resistance. Option: C . Frequent and prior use of topical antibiotics or steroid preparation: this is causative, as increased use of topical steroids and antibiotics can cause bacterial infections.

questions.text: The new-born pictured was born at home and has puffy, tense eyelids, red conjunctiva, a copious amount of purulent ocular discharge, and chemosis 2 days after birth. The most likely diagnosis is:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Gonococcal ophthalmia

Highyeild:

Clinical feature of Gonococcal ophthalmia : Onset is hyperacute (12 to 24 hours) Symptoms include: Pain that is moderate to severe, purulent discharge, which is usually copious, and Swelling of the eyelids , which is usually marked. Signs The eyelids are tense and swollen. Tenderness is marked. The discharge is thick, purulent, and copious, trickling down the cheeks. The conjunctiva shows marked chemosis, congestion, and papillae, giving it a bright red, velvety appearance. Frequently, a pseudomembrane may be seen on the conjunctival surface. Preauricular lymph nodes are usually enlarged and tender. Associations: Gonococcal conjunctivitis is usually associated with urethritis and arthritis . Complications: Corneal involvement results in diffuse haze and oedema, central necrosis, corneal ulceration, or even perforation. Iridocyclitis . Systemic complications, though rare, include gonorrhoea, arthritis, endocarditis, and septicaemia. Treatment Systemic therapy: Third- generation cephalosporins such as cefoxitim 1.0 gm, cefotaxime 500 mg IV q.i.d., or ceftriaxone 1.0 gm IM q.i.d., all for 5 days; should be preferred treatments. Quinolones such as norfloxacin (1.2 gm orally q.i.d.,) for 5 days, or Spectinomycin 2.0 mg IM for 3 days may be used alternatively. All of the above regimens should then be followed by a one - week course of either doxycycline 100 mg biweekly or erythromycin 250–500 mg orally q.i.d. Topical antibiotic therapy , presently recommended, includes ofloxacin, ciprofloxacin, or tobramycin eye drops or bacitracin or erythromycin eye ointment every 2 hours for the first 2–3 days and then 5 times daily for 7 days. Irrigation of the eyes frequently with sterile saline Topical atropine 1% eye drops should be instilled once or twice a day if the cornea is involved.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Dacryocystitis: Findings: Eye pain, swelling around your eye, redness or skin darkening, an abscess or sore that may have discharge (pus) in the inner corner of your eyelids , fever Option: B . Chemical conjunctivitis: The chemical type of conjunctivitis may be caused by irritants such as chlorine (in swimming pools), smoke, or fumes. Symptoms of Conjunctivitis Discharge or crusting on eyelids. Watery eyes or excessive tearing. Sandy or scratchy feeling in the eye. Sensitivity to light. Eye pain. Option: C. Pneumococcal ophthalmia: Pneumoniae conjunctivitis is commonly associated with outbreaks involving people in close living quarters, such as college dorms, nursing homes, military bases, and daycare centres. Symptoms of bacterial conjunctivitis include redness of the eye, purulent discharge lasting all day, eyelid edema, and discomfort or pain.

questions.text: A 13-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his mother because of a 6-hour history of severe eye pain and blurry vision. He wears soft contact lenses and has not removed them for two days. Ophthalmologic examination shows a deep corneal ulcer, severe conjunctival injection, and purulent discharge on the right. Treatment with topical ciprofloxacin is initiated. A culture of the ocular discharge is most likely to show which of the following?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Gram-negative, Oxidase-positive bacilli The patient's severe eye pain, corneal ulcer, and purulent discharge are consistent with bacterial keratitis . Pseudomonas aeruginosa is the most common cause of bacterial keratitis in contact lens users ( > 60% of cases). Pseudomonas aeruginosa is a gramme-negative, oxidase-positive, catalase-positive, non-lactose fermenting encapsulated bacillius . Prompt antibiotic therapy is required to prevent complications such as corneal scarring and loss of vision. Ciprofloxacin, aminoglycosides (e.g., gentamicin), and polymyxin B are effective against P. aeruginosa and are used topically to treat keratitis . Other antibiotics that are effective against P. aeruginosa include ceftazidime, cefepime, piperacillin-tazobactam, and ticarcillin, but these antibiotics are typically used systemically.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Staphylococcus aureus (gramme-positive, coagulase-positive cocci) is a relatively common cause of keratitis, and ciprofloxacin would cover S. aureus but aureus, is not the most common cause of bacterial keratitis in contact lens users. Option: B. Gramme-negative, lactose-fermenting bacilli such as Escherichia coli and Klebsiella pneumoniae can cause keratitis, and ciprofloxacin can be used to treat infections with these organisms. However, these pathogens are not the most common cause of bacterial keratitis in contact lens users. In this case, the most likely pathogen is a lactose non-fermenter. Option: C. Streptococcus pyogenes (gramme-positive, bacitracin-sensitive cocci) causes keratitis only in rare cases. This bacterium typically causes scarlet fever, acute otitis media, and soft tissue infections (e.g., erysipelas, cellulitis, and impetigo). Additionally, ciprofloxacin is not the ideal treatment because S. pyogenes shows mild resistance to fluoroquinolones. Typically, beta-lactam antibiotics (e.g., penicillin, amoxicillin, and second-generation cephalosporins) are the first-line treatment.

questions.text: A patient with a corneal ulcer came in with pus in the anterior chamber. Which of the following statements is not true regarding this case?

options.label: B
options.text: The pus is formed due to the outpouring of leucocytes from iritis or iridocyclitis

options.label: C
options.text: It is necessary to remove the pus immediately to avoid further complications.

options.label: D
options.text: In recalcitrant fungal ulcers, an anterior chamber tap should be done to check for fungal invasion.

questions.correct_answer: C. It is necessary to remove the pus immediately to avoid further complications.
questions.explanation:
Solution:

It is necessary to remove the pus immediately to avoid further complications. The given case history and findings point towards the diagnosis of hypopyon. A hypopyon consists of polymorphonuclear leukocytes that accumulate in the lower angle of the anterior chamber and eventually become enmeshed in a network of fibrin. It is clinically seen in severe corneal ulcers as a collection of pus' in the anterior chamber. It is usually unnecessary to remove the pus , as is the rule in other parts of the body; if the ulcerative process is controlled, the hypopyon will be absorbed.

Highyeild:

Hypopyon A hypopyon consists of polymorphonuclear leukocytes that accumulate in the lower angle of the anterior chamber and eventually become enmeshed in a network of fibrin . It is clinically seen in severe corneal ulcers as a collection of ‘pus’ in the anterior chamber . Corneal ulcers are associated with some iritis owing to the diffusion of toxins released by bacteria or the invasion of organisms such as fungal hyphae into the eye . The resultant iridocyclitis is severe, leading to the outpouring of leucocytes from the vessels, and these cells gravitate to the bottom of the anterior chamber to form a hypopyon. The development of a hypopyon depends on two factors: (i) the virulence of the infecting organism and (ii) resistance of the tissues. Many pyogenic organisms (staphylococci, streptococci, gonococci,pneumococci, Pseudomonas pyocyanea, etc.) may produce this result, but unless the organism is very virulent, some lack of resistance on the part of the tissues must be present. Hence, hypopyon ulcers are much more common in old, debilitated or alcoholic subjects. It is important to remember that a hypopyon is usually sterile since the leukocytes are due to toxins, not to actual invasion by bacteria, which,indeed, are as incapable of passing through the intact Descemet’s membrane as leukocytes. This accounts for the ease and rapidity with which the Hypopyon is often absorbed. It may develop in an hour or two, rapidly disappear, and then readily reappear. A hypopyon is fluid, always moving to the lowest part of the anterior chamber depending on the position of the patient’s head. It may be so small that it is scarcely visible, being hidden behind the rim of sclera, which overlaps the cornea. It may reach halfway up the iris,having a flat upper surface, determined by gravity, or it may fill the anterior chamber, wholly obscuring the iris. The hypopyon, if fluid, will be seen to shift, i.e., a change in fluid level with tilting or a change in position of the head . A larger hypopyon and that which is due to fungal infections are usually less fluid owing to the fibrinous network, which imprisons the leucocytes in its meshes, and direct invasion by fungal hyphae. These are immobile and are much less readily absorbed. It is usually unnecessary to remove the pus, as is the rule in other parts of the body; if the ulcerative process is controlled, the hypopyon will be absorbed . However, in some cases of recalcitrant fungal ulcers, an anterior chamber tap to test the hypopyon for fungal invasion, followed by an anterior chamber wash with antifungals, may be required.
